facts.text: Appellant and respondents 1 to 3 contested the last general elections from the Dharmapuri Parliamentary Constituency in the district of Salem in the State of Madras.
Respondents 4 to 10 were added subsequently by order of the Tribunal; their nominations were held valid but they withdrew candidature before polling.
Appellant was declared elected to the House of the People.

On 5th March 1952, 1st respondent filed election petition before Election Commission contesting appellant's election on ground of disqualification under section 7(d) of Representation of the People Act, 1951, as appellant had contract with Government of India in Postal Department for transport of postal mail from date of nomination until date of election and after.

Appellant holds stage carriage service permit Ex. B-2 dated 26th April 1949 issued by Regional Transport Authority, Salem, Madras, with condition that if called upon, appellant will enter agreement with Government of India for transport of postal articles and mail bags.
Appellant entered registered agreement Ex. A-3 with Government of India on 16th November 1949 for transport of postal articles and mail bags.

After appellant filed nomination paper, 1st respondent by petition dated 28th November 1951 objected to nomination on ground of contract with Government of India for transport of mail between Salem and Yercaud.

Returning Officer for Dharmapuri Parliamentary Constituency by order Ex. A-2 dated 28th November 1951 overruled objection, holding service rendered under imperative order under Rule 160-B of Madras Motor Vehicles Rules, not under agreement (registered agreement Ex. A-3 not placed before him).
Appellant filed written statement on 28th May 1952 denying disqualification under section 7(d).

Election Tribunal, North Arcot, Vellore by orders dated 20th January 1953 in Election Petition No. 35 of 1952 held appellant disqualified under section 7(d), allowed petition, declared election void under section 100(1)(c) with costs to respondent.

Agreement Ex. A-3 from 15th December 1949 to 14th December 1952; appellant (contractor) to convey postal articles and mail bags by motor vehicles; permitted to carry passengers if mail not prejudiced; maintain buses at own expense; penalties for delays; liable for safe custody; free travel for postal officers; no transfer without consent; remuneration Rs. 200 per month adjustable by mileage; terminable by 4 months notice; arbitration clause.

Rule 160-B of Madras Motor Vehicles Rules: Condition of every stage carriage permit that holder shall, if required by transport authority, carry mails at rates and terms fixed after consultation with holder and postal authorities.

legal_issues.text: Whether the appellant is disqualified under section 7(d) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951 for election to the House of the People.
Whether the Tribunal has jurisdiction to decide disqualification in view of article 103 of the Constitution of India.

petitioner_arguments.text: Carrying mails is exclusive privilege of Government of India, normal function statutorily reserved, not performance of any service undertaken by Government.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951 section 7(d)

petitioner_arguments.text: No interest in contract for performance of any service undertaken by appropriate Government; carrying out obligations under Rule 160-B of Madras Motor Vehicles Rules.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Motor Vehicles Act section 48(d); Madras Motor Vehicles Rules rule 160-B

petitioner_arguments.text: Agreement lacks free consensus, offer and acceptance; statutory obligation, not contract.
No consideration as remuneration fixed by Regional Transport Officer on 23rd July 1949 is subsidy; agreement with third party (Governor-General) for service due to another (Transport Authority).
Transport of mail not a service undertaken by Central Government.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Indian Post Office Act, 1898; Representation of the People Act, 1951 section 7(d)

petitioner_arguments.text: Question of disqualification to be decided by President under article 103, Tribunal lacks jurisdiction.

respondent_arguments.text: Appellant disqualified under section 7(d) as he had contract with Government of India Postal Department for transport of postal mail.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951 section 7(d)

respondent_arguments.text: Postal service including transport of mails is service undertaken by Central Government; appellant was contractor under agreement involving mutual obligations, free offer and acceptance, valid consideration.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Representation of the People Act, 1951 section 7(d)

court_reasoning.text: Agreement Ex. A-3 is formal contract satisfying requirements; entered with eyes open; not compelled; could terminate by 4 months notice under clause 18.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Agreement has all ingredients of valid contract under Indian Contract Act: competent parties, free consent, lawful consideration.

court_reasoning.text: Rule 160-B imposes condition on permit but agreement is independent contract with own terms; not pre-existing obligation extinguishing contract.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Permit condition is notice to applicants; holder free not to apply if unwilling.

court_reasoning.text: Valid consideration: cash payment separate from permit; fixed after consultation.
Postal service is undertaken by Government as welfare service, not essential sovereign function; contract for such service falls within section 7(d).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Straightforward illustration of contract contemplated by section 7(d).

court_reasoning.text: Section 7(d) avoids conflict between public duty and private interest; appellant had choice to terminate contract.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant directly concerned for own benefit in contract.

court_reasoning.text: Article 103 not bar to Tribunal's jurisdiction.

holdings.text: Appellant disqualified under section 7(d) of Representation of the People Act, 1951; agreement is valid contract for service undertaken by Government.

statutes_cited.name: Representation of the People Act, 1951
statutes_cited.relevance: Disqualification for interest in contract for services undertaken by Government; grounds for declaring election void.

statutes_cited.name: Madras Motor Vehicles Rules
statutes_cited.relevance: Condition of stage carriage permit to carry mails if required.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Post Office Act, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Exclusive privilege of conveying postal articles; enabling provisions for postal service.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs validity of agreement: free consent, consideration.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: President decides disqualification; not bar to Tribunal jurisdiction here.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld Election Tribunal's order declaring appellant's election void under section 100(1)(c) of Representation of the People Act, 1951 on ground of disqualification under section 7(d); conclusions of Tribunal correct.
outcome.relief_granted: Election petition allowed by Tribunal; appeal dismissed.
outcome.costs: Costs awarded to respondent by Tribunal (not altered).

key_quotes.text: "Section 7 of the Act is clearly intended to avoid a conflict between public duty and private interest."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "The present case is a straightforward illustration of the kind of contract contemplated by section 7(d) of the Act."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "At all material times the appellant has been directly concerned, for his own benefit, in the contract of carrying mail bags and postal articles."
key_quotes.speaker: court
